conclusion: Determine the time of collision between Car A and Car B based on the given v-t graph.
The vertical axis represents velocity v in meters per second (m·s⁻¹), ranging from 0 to 25 m·s⁻¹. The horizontal axis represents time t in seconds (s), ranging from 0 to 30 s.
Line A starts at a higher initial velocity and decreases linearly. Line B starts at a lower initial velocity and also decreases linearly.
Both cars start braking simultaneously when they hear the siren, and the collision occurs at the point where their velocity-time paths intersect, as indicated by the red dot.
The red dot is positioned at t = 25 s on the time axis and at a velocity slightly above 0 m·s⁻¹.
The red dot represents the moment of collision. From the graph, this point lies at t = 25 s.
The collision occurs 25 seconds after the braking began.
The question asks whether the collision occurs before or after 20 seconds of braking.
Since the collision happens at t = 25 s, which is after 20 seconds, we need to confirm this by analyzing the relative motion and braking behavior.
Both cars are braking, meaning their velocities are decreasing over time.
Line A has a steeper slope than Line B, indicating Car A decelerates more rapidly.
Line B has a gentler slope, indicating Car B decelerates more slowly.
The collision occurs when Car A catches up to Car B, which happens at the intersection point (red dot) at t = 25 s.
Since both cars are moving in the same direction and Car A is behind Car B, the collision implies that Car A's position becomes equal to Car B's position at this time.
The intersection point indicates the time when the distance between the cars becomes zero (collision).
The graph shows that at t = 25 s, the velocities are close to zero, and this is the point of intersection, confirming the collision time.
The collision occurs at t = 25 s, which is 5 seconds after 20 seconds.
Therefore, the collision happens after 20 seconds of braking.
The two cars collide after 20 seconds of braking.
